intro: Corydalis govaniana var. malukiana, commonly known as the Maluku corydalis, is a flowering plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Papaveraceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests or mountainous regions. It has slender, branched stems and lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The flowers are borne in clusters and are adapted for pollination by insects, particularly bees.
